tossups.question: Counterintuitively, a first-order Lindemann (“LIN-de-min”) mechanism requires one of these events to activate “A” into “A-star.” The rate of these events, symbolized Z, is the ratio between the frequency and steric factors and is approximated as [read slowly] “sigma, times root eight pi k B T, over reduced mass.” Molecular chaos assumes velocity is uncorrelated in the interval between these events, during which a molecule moves one (*) mean free path. The Arrhenius pre-exponential factor equals the frequency of these events times the probability they occur at proper orientation. The ideal gas law can be derived by using the force of these events to define pressure. For 10 points, kinetic molecular theory assumes what events are always elastic?
tossups.answer: particle collisions [or collision theory; accept any synonymous answers indicating molecules colliding or hitting each other or the walls of their containers; prompt on interactions between particles; reject “reactions”]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~25692~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: In a novel by this author, a dying man gives a “perhaps gracious, perhaps mocking” smile. A boy created by this author dreams about a sparrow hawk and sees the Mark of Cain on his classmates. Before LSD sessions, Timothy Leary advised reading a book by this man whose protagonist hears the “song of the thousand voices.” The Gnostic deity Abraxas is studied by Emil Sinclair in this author’s novel (*) Demian. His grandfather’s time in Kerala inspired one of this author’s books in which a monk protects a man from snakes by a river. The title character of that novel by this author abandons asceticism, falls in love with the courtesan Kamala, meets the ferryman Vasudeva, and gains enlightenment. For 10 points, name this German author of Siddhartha.
tossups.answer: Hermann Hesse [or Hermann Karl Hesse]
tossups.metadata: Ai Xing, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~27871~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

tossups.question: In a 1929 debate, this person humiliated Lothrop Stoddard for claiming that Stoddard’s system of “bi-racialism” did not mean discrimination. This person used letters written to Franklin Sanborn to write a 1909 biography of John Brown. This person paired poetry with unrelated sheet music to begin the chapters of a book that ends by describing “sorrow songs.” This person employed Walter (*) White at his newspaper, The Crisis. This person wrote “the problem of the 20th century is the problem of the color line” in the introduction to a collection that challenged Booker T. Washington’s ideas on Black education. For 10 points, The Souls of Black Folk was written by what African-American activist who founded the NAACP?
tossups.answer: W. E. B. Du Bois (“doo-BOYS”) [or William Edward Burghardt Du Bois]
tossups.metadata: Hari Parameswaran, History - American - 1865-1945> ~23892~ <Editor: Arjun Nageswaran

tossups.question: Jim Marshall gained fame for photographing people in this profession, including one in Monterey, California lighting an object on fire. William Gottlieb is best known for photographing members of this profession. Harry Benson photographed a group of people in this profession having a pillow fight. One person in this profession flips his middle finger to the camera in a photo of him taken in San Quentin Prison. On the day a member of this profession (*) died, Annie Leibovitz photographed him naked cuddling his wife. A Volkswagen can be seen in the background of a photograph of four people in this profession crossing a street. For 10 points, name this occupation of those photographed on stage at Woodstock.
tossups.answer: musician [accept any answer indicating people who play music; accept guitarist or guitar player; accept singer; accept rockstar; accept rock musician; accept band musicians or members; accept jazz musician or artist; prompt on artist; prompt on actor by asking “what other profession was that person most famous for?”]
tossups.metadata: Lalit Maharjan, Fine Arts - Photography> ~28636~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: A word translated as “veerition” was coined by a poem in this language whose final line imagines fishing the “tongue of the night” in a “great black hole.” That poem in this language repeatedly mentions an inert town “at the end of daybreak.” A poet in this language wrote the collection Nocturnes and poems “Prayer to Masks” and “Black Woman.” (*) The author of “Notebook of a Return to My Native Land.”used this language to describe Caliban demanding to be called “X” in the play A Tempest. While a head-of-state in 1983, Léopold Senghor was elected as the first African member of this language’s “Academy.” For 10 points, name this language used by Négritude authors from Martinique and Senegal.
tossups.answer: French [or française; accept the Académie française] (Windward Heights is by Maryse Condé, “Notebook of a Return to My Native Land” is by Aimé Césaire)
tossups.metadata: Yingzhi Nyang, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~28015~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: Description acceptable. To protect against these events, spy and TV chef Julia Child developed a recipe including clove oil and horse urine. Achen and Bartels argued that “retrospective voting” following some of these events in 1916 contributed to Charles Evans Hughes winning New Jersey over Woodrow Wilson. The musical Bruce gets its title from a malfunctioning prop used in a film centering on these events. That film adaptation of a (*) Peter Benchley novel about these events added an iconic monologue about the USS Indianapolis. That same 1975 film centering on these events popularized the “blockbuster” release strategy and contains the iconic line, “You’re going to need a bigger boat.” For 10 points, name these events depicted in Jaws.
tossups.answer: shark attacks [accept more specific answers like Great White Shark attacks or anything having to do with sharks mauling or killing people; prompt on killings or animal attacks]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~27334~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: A practice in these places was inspired by a leader’s decision to engage in “true business” by feeding and clothing naked holy men with his father’s money. Water is forbidden from being placed beneath a cot in these locations on which an object is covered by rumalla garments. Worshippers sit cross-legged in the diwan hall of these locations where a sewadar serves a wheat (*) pudding to cupped hands. Saffron-colored flags emblazoned with the khanda are commonly erected outside these locations, which contain a “living teacher” in the form of a sacred text held in a takht throne. Community kitchens called langars are located within, for 10 points, what places of worship which venerate the Adi Granth and are exemplified by Amritsar’s Golden Temple?
tossups.answer: gurdwaras [or gurudwaras; accept Sikh temples; prompt on langars or kitchens before “langar” is read by asking “of what larger locations?”; prompt on temples by asking “of what faith?”]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, RMP - Other Religion> ~28221~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: In 1991, Sherrie Levine created a bronze copy of this artwork subtitled “Madonna.” Glyn Thompson has argued that an object in this artwork had to have been created in Philadelphia and should be attributed to Baroness Elsa von Freytag-Loringhoven. This work was called a cross between “a Buddha and a Veiled Woman” in a photo of it by Alfred Stieglitz. In contrast to claims made in the 1960s, this artwork was likely not based on an object purchased from the J . L. (*) Mott Iron Works. Despite rules accepting all submissions, this work was not displayed at a 1917 exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists. This work is signed “R. Mutt.” For 10 points, name this readymade attributed to Marcel Duchamp, adapted from a urinal.
tossups.answer: Fountain
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Sculpture> ~27822~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: In these features, strain rate is approximately proportional to the cube of basal shear stress according to Glen’s flow law. These features’ equilibrium line altitudes may limit vertical growth as they act as hypothetical “buzzsaws.” Firn increases in density and undergoes pore closure before being incorporated into these features. A disappearance of many of these features caused isostatic rebound. These objects’ “health” is measured by their (*) mass balance, which is negative during these features’ climate change-driven “retreat.” These features can leave behind namesake lakes and form moraines by depositing till. For 10 points, name these large, slow-moving masses of ice.
tossups.answer: glaciers [prompt on glacial ice; prompt on ice sheets by asking, “what features compose ice sheets?”]
tossups.metadata: Benjamin Chapman, Science - Earth> ~25999~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: An Oscar-nominated 1976 film about this person triggered an incident where Marion Barry was shot and 100 other DC residents were taken hostage. A journalist known as “Charb” contributed to a 2013 “Life” of this person, earning his place on a most-wanted list. In 2006, a controversy named for this person resulted in widespread protests against the Jyllands-Posten (“yew-lens poss-ten”) newspaper at numerous (*) Danish embassies. In 2010, Molly Norris organized a “day” named for this person after Viacom censored a Trey Parker and Matt Stone TV episode about him. After cartoons of this person were published, a mass shooting took place at the offices of Charlie Hebdo. For 10 points, name this founder of Islam.
tossups.answer: Muhammad [accept Mohammad, Messenger of God or the Prophet Muhammad]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25725~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: Vortices and anti-vortices are paired by the “BKT” one of these phenomena. The nature of these phenomena in the 2D Potts model depends on whether the number of states exceeds four. Mean-field theory is typically introduced with these phenomena as a motivating example. These phenomena correspond to symmetry group changes in Landau theory. The “order” of these phenomena depends on whether they feature continuous change in energy with the (*) order parameter. The Ising (“EE-zing”) model gains spontaneous magnetization via these phenomena. These phenomena occur when state variables cross a coexistence curve, but do not exceed its critical point. For 10 points, name these phenomena in which the state of matter changes.
tossups.answer: phase transitions [or phase changes; prompt on transitions; prompt on BKT transitions with “what broader class of phenomena does the BKT transition exemplify?”]
tossups.metadata: David Bass, Science - Physics> ~28564~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: One piece of this type opens with the melody [read slowly] “long D, down to G, D, long E-flat” and features a “Scotch snap” rhythm in its second movement scherzo. A six movement work of this type was inspired by a folk genre that suddenly shifts from melancholy to exuberance. Clara Schumann’s Opus 17 is a G minor work of this type. One piece of this type got its nickname because its eerie Largo movement reminded Carl Czerny (“CHAIR-nee”) of Hamlet’s father. Antonín Dvořák’s (“duh-VOR-zhahk’s”) fourth work of this type is subtitled (*) “Dumky.” A Beethoven work of this type is nicknamed for its dedicatee, Rudolf of Austria. “Ghost” and “Archduke” are, for 10 points, what type of piece written for an ensemble of violin, cello, and a namesake keyboard instrument?
tossups.answer: piano trio [prompt on trio]
tossups.metadata: Ivvone Zhou, Fine Arts - Music - Romantic> ~27612~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

tossups.question: This man reduced the Anglican Church’s influence at Cambridge after winning a surprisingly close election against the Earl of Powis to become its chancellor. In a speech at Exeter Hall, this man publicly endorsed Thomas Fowell-Buxton’s efforts to abolish slavery. For an event organized by Henry Cole and this man, banana cultivator Joseph (*) Paxton erected a building made from cast iron and plate glass. The Kohinoor diamond was exhibited at an event organized by this man often named for the quickly-constructed building in which it was held, the Crystal Palace. This grandfather of Nicholas II of Russia was mourned by his wife for 40 years following his 1861 death. For 10 points, name this husband of Queen Victoria.
tossups.answer: Prince Albert [or Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - European - 1500-1900> ~27338~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: Another author cited this author’s “conversation” for a 1926 novel’s epigraph that originated as a comment about a mechanic who fixed this author’s Ford. This author repeated the line “when this you see remember me” in a libretto for Virgil Thomson’s Four Saints in Three Acts. This author co-hosted Saturday evening meetings at 27 Rue de Fleurus (“ROO duh fluh-ROO”), one of whose attendees, (*) Ernest Hemingway, said that this author coined the phrase “lost generation.” This author wrote an oft-quoted repetitive line of her poem “Sacred Emily” while living as an American expatriate in Paris. For 10 points, what author of The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas wrote “Rose is a rose is a rose is a rose”?
tossups.answer: Gertrude Stein (The first line refers to the first epigraph of Hemingway’s The Sun Also Rises.)
tossups.metadata: Joseph Krol, Literature - American - Misc> ~28205~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: “Africa [does this action]” in the title of a book by Claudia Zaslavsky. Comparisons can be made without performing this symbolic process thanks to a “sense” encoded in the brain by the ANS and the parallel individuation system. For very small inputs, this process is replaced by the near-instantaneous, visual process of subitizing. In a classic study of selective attention, participants are asked to perform this process for passes made by a (*) basketball team, but may fail to notice a man in a gorilla suit in the process. Children with dys·cal·culia may have difficulty performing this sequential process backwards or without use of their fingers. For 10 points, name this process used to determine the number of objects in a set.
tossups.answer: counting [accept word forms such as counts or taking a count; accept Africa Counts; prompt on adding or subtracting or doing math; prompt on quantifying or determining number; prompt on watching or observing or synonyms]
tossups.metadata: Vincent Du, Social Science - Psychology> ~28565~ <Editor: Vincent Du

tossups.question: S-RNases kill cells in this substance if they have the same S-haplotype as papilla cells. The round allele for exines in this substance was William Bateson’s first example of a linked gene. This substance is transferred to unsuspecting targets by pseudocopulation. Self-incompatibility ensures allogamous transfer of this substance. Generative cells in this substance divide inside vegetative cells, then descend a (*) tube into the style. This substance’s resilient walls have three apertures in dicots (“DIE-cots”). Gregor Mendel physically moved this substance to do test crosses. Male gameto·phytes in this substance are transferred from anthers to stigmas by wind or insects. For 10 points, name this sticky grain emitted by flowers.
tossups.answer: pollen [accept pollen tube; accept pollen grains; prompt on male gametophytes until read; reject “nectar”]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Biology> ~27658~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: Over 80,000 citizens of this president’s country have uploaded geotagged photos on Diia for property damage claims. Simon Shuster’s 2024 biography The Showman criticizes this politician’s propagandist Telemarathon United News. Article 108 of a 1996 constitution has allowed this politician to stay in power despite his term ending on May 20, 2024. Shortly after this politician called for “timely support” in a joint press conference with (*) Jens Stoltenberg, Congress passed the REPO Act granting his country assets seized from oligarchs. This former star of Servant of the People was the chief beneficiary of a 95 billion dollar military aid package passed by Speaker Mike Johnson in April 2024. For 10 points, name this president of Ukraine.
tossups.answer: Volodymyr Zelensky [or Volodymyr Oleksandrovych Zelenskyy]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~27337~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: These creatures’ liver was mixed with egg-yolk to produce St. Hildegard’s leprosy-curing ointment. A bovine creature of this type is depicted alongside an “incense burner” or “sacred filter” on Indus seals. The re’em (“reh-em”) and the “Indian ass” of the Greeks were conflated with these creatures, which could purify water by making the sign of the cross. Hunters tied naked (*) virgins to trees in order to entrap these “lewd” creatures who were attracted to their purity. On a coat of arms, the lion is portrayed opposite to one of these goat-bearded creatures, which are Scotland’s national animal. European nobility mistook walrus and narwhal ivory for these creatures’ alicorns. For 10 points, name these single-horned horses.
tossups.answer: unicorns [or monoceros]
tossups.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - World Mythology> ~27140~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: This character confesses a fear of air-guns after he narrowly avoids being killed by a two-horse van, a falling brick, and a bludgeon, all in the same day. In his death note, this character admits he immediately knew that the story about a sick Englishwoman at an inn in Meiringen was a hoax. This character returned from a few months’ exile in Tibet after 20,000 (*) readers wrote letters to The Strand complaining about his death. This master of baritsu wins a fistfight atop a Swiss waterfall with a math professor dubbed “the Napoleon of Crime.” At the start of “The Final Problem,” Professor Moriarty tracks this character to his Baker Street residence. For 10 points, name this detective created by Arthur Conan Doyle.
tossups.answer: Sherlock Holmes [or Sherlock Holmes]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Literature - British - Short Fiction> ~27773~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: This politician’s declaration that “the respect for the rights of others is peace” has long been a political rallying cry. After returning from exile, this politician attached his name to a law that ended a separate legal system for the military and clergy. The Convention of London was a response to this politician declaring a two-year postponement of debt repayments. The church-backed Felix (*) Zuloaga opposed this politician in the Reform War. This leader declared a national holiday after French troops under Charles de Lorencez (“loh-rehn-say”) failed to seize the fortifications at Puebla. This Zapotec speaker was elected governor of his native state of Oaxaca. For 10 points, name this first indigenous president of Mexico.
tossups.answer: Benito Juarez [or Benito Pablo Juárez García]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - World - Latin American> ~27438~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: The cosmic background in this region of the electromagnetic spectrum shows that the star formation rate peaked at a redshift between one and two. Certain objects that primarily emit in this region are classified with spectral types L, T, or Y. This region dominates black body radiation from interstellar dust. To observe this region, one telescope uses a five-layer sunshield composed of Kapton E to protect its (*) hexagonal mirrors. To observe galaxies at unprecedented redshifts, the James Webb Space Telescope observes in this region. Brown dwarfs emit in this region because they are cooler than main sequence stars. For 10 points, name this region of the electromagnetic spectrum that precedes visible light in frequency.
tossups.answer: infrared [or IR; accept cosmic infrared background; accept near infrared; accept near IR; accept far infrared; accept far IR; prompt on CIB] (The second sentence describes the stellar classification of red and brown dwarfs.)
tossups.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, Science - Astronomy> ~28072~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: Supersessionist theology holds that one of these relationships with the people of Israel was abrogated. For 10 points each:
parts: Prophets like Abraham held what holy relationship with God, which names a lost “ark?”

In Corinthians, Paul wrote that the new covenant gives life by having us act as ministers of this concept rather than the “letter” of the old covenant which brought death. John 3:6 (“chapter 3, verse 6”) states that this concept births itself just as flesh gives birth to flesh.
This denomination renews their covenant on the first Sunday of the year. George Whitefield and John Wesley belonged to this Protestant denomination, which was the first to preach on outward holiness.
answers: the Spirit [accept the Holy Spirit; accept the Holy Ghost; reject “ghost”]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, RMP - Christian Practice> ~22147~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: The movement of glucose through proteins called GLUTs (“glutes”) is a textbook example of this type of passive transport. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process by which polar molecules diffuse into the cell through a helper protein that is docked in the membrane.
By contrast, active transport of glucose occurs in this organ’s renal tubules, where it is coupled to the removal of sodium from the filtrate of the glomerulus.

The aptly named “Sugars Will Eventually be Exported Transporters,” or SWEETs, exchange sugars without ATP and are in a superfamily named for these light-sensitive GPCRs. Retinal is usually found attached to these proteins.
answers: facilitated diffusion [or facilitated transport; prompt on passive mediated transport]
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Biology> ~23262~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: This instrument is classified as an indirectly struck idiophone because its sound is created by beads or pebbles rattling inside of a gourd. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Latin American rattle with a handle that is often played in pairs, as in some traditional Mexican music.

A handheld Latin American shaker in the shape of these objects is commonly used to teach music to children. A product made from these objects may lend its name to the national dance of the Dominican Republic.
Rattles from this country called the cabasa and the ganzá are central to a type of its folk music that evolved into a genre whose name translates to “new wave.”
answers: Brazil [or Federative Republic of Brazil or República Federativa do Brasil] (The unnamed genres are samba (or batucada) and bossa nova.)
bonuses.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Miscellaneous> ~23213~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

bonuses.leadin: Germaine de Staël (“STAHL”) established the Coppet literary salon after she was exiled for criticizing this man. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man. In another novel, this man declares “That’s a fine death!” before saving an enemy soldier, who views him as an “insignificant creature.”

This author responded to de Staël’s criticism in his complimentary A Life of Napoleon, but later depicted Napoleon more harshly, as shown in a scene showing Fabrizio del Dongo wandering around at the Battle of Waterloo in The Charterhouse of Parma.
Napoleon saves Prince Andrei in this Tolstoy novel, in which Pierre Bezukhov decides Napoleon is the Antichrist.
bonuses.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~22675~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

bonuses.leadin: Two answers required. The dot product of these two quantities is added to the divergence of the Poynting vector in Poynting’s theorem to represent the rate of work on charges. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these two quantities whose ratio equals resistivity according to a “continuum” form of Ohm’s law that is derived by dividing both sides by length.
Poynting’s theorem gives an equation for this operation on negative energy density. Applying this operation to charge yields current.
The Poynting vector equals the cross product of the electric field and the field “auxiliary” to this field, which is denoted with a bold “B.”
answers: electric field AND current density [accept in either order; accept E-field instead of “electric field”; prompt on E instead of “electric field”; prompt on j instead of “current density”]

partial time derivative [or partial derivative with respect to time or differentiation with respect to time; prompt on partial derivative by asking “with respect to what quantity?”; prompt on answers describing dividing by time by asking, “what is the analog of that operation in calculus?”]
bonuses.metadata: David Bass, Science - Physics> ~22502~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: In the 1920s, this author worked at the Brunner-Mond chemical plant where the Haber process was first commercialized in Britain. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author who was inspired by that factory to name a character “Mustapha Mond” in his novel Brave New World.
Though mostly complimentary to Alfred Mond, Brave New World is harsher to this real-life contemporary, whose lifetime defines year zero in the World State’s calendar.

Aldous Huxley hinted at the dystopian future he would write about in Brave New World through a vision by Mr. Scogan in this novel which has a title resembling a chemical. Denis Stone attends a party in this first published novel by Aldous Huxley.
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~22177~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: In 1022, Robert II ordered 14 people in this city be burned at the stake for heresy, the first such punishment in Western Europe. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city whose university was established in 1306 by Pope Clement V. The Battle of the Herrings gets its name from the supplies sent to forces besieging this city.
This woman rallied French troops during the Siege of Orléans. She was burned at the stake by the English in 1431.
This graduate of the University of Orléans went into hiding after his colleague Nicolas Cop gave a heretical address in 1533. Twenty years later, this theologian condemned Michael Servetus.
answers: Joan of Arc [or Jeanne d’Arc; or Jehanne d’Arc; prompt on Joan or Jeanne or Jehanne]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - European - Middle Ages> ~22556~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: Hungarian composers Emmerich Kálmán and Franz Lehár are best known for a style of operetta named for this city. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city, whose busy opera house was the first major building on its Ringstrasse, or Ring Road. The waltz was popularized in this city.

This dance and the word “princess” titles Kálmán’s best known Viennese operetta. In an operetta by Johann Strauss II, Rosalinde pretends to be a countess by describing the “Sounds of my homeland” while imitating this traditional Hungarian folk dance.
That csárdás appears in this operetta by Johann Strauss II, in which Adele sings a “Laughing Song” at Prince Orlofsky’s ball.
bonuses.metadata: Ivvone Zhou, Fine Arts - Opera> ~22639~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

bonuses.leadin: An English message on this object states how it was “PRESENTED BY KING GEORGE III.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this stele with three different versions of a decree of Ptolemy V that was used to decipher Egyptian Hieroglyphics.

The Myazedi Inscription, the “Rosetta Stone of Southeast Asia,” helped scholars decipher the Pyu script for this language. A collection of scriptures named for this language is divided into the Tripiṭaka or “Triple Basket.”

Bilingual coins issued by King Agathocles of this kingdom have been called “little Rosetta stones” for helping scholars decipher Indian scripts. By 128 BCE, this kingdom was paying tribute to the Yuèzhī people.
answers: Bactria [accept Greco-Bactrian Kingdom or Bactriana or Zariaspa or Baktrianē or Bāhlīka]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~22875~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: Activist Terri Jean proposed five origins for this pop culture trope about these places, including settler guilt, manifest destiny, and simple convenience. For 10 points each:
parts: The Amityville Horror is the likely cinematic origin of the cursed tropes about what sacred places which are disturbed by haunted facilities like Lake Shawnee’s Amusement Park?
Following the Curse of Tippecanoe, years divisible by 20 foretell the end of these “Great White Fathers.” A holder of this post may have cut down a cherry tree.
Chief Niwot uttered the Curse of Boulder Valley upon meeting people engaged in this activity. Herodotus claimed that “ants” engaged in this activity in India.
answers: Indian burial ground [accept cemeteries and graveyards and similar in place of burial ground]
presidents of the United States [accept presidents of the US; accept Commander-in-Chief; prompt on America for “US”; prompt on president by asking “of where?”]
gold-digging [accept gold-prospecting; accept searching for gold or mining for gold and similar; prompt on digging or mining or prospecting by asking “for what”]

bonuses.leadin: Many paintings in Edward Hicks’s Peaceable Kingdom series depict this man conversing with followers in the background. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this historical figure who wears a green vest and kneels away from the viewer while surrounded by men in tricornes and headdresses in a 1772 painting.

This American artist and court painter for King George III created Penn’s Treaty with the Indians. In another painting by this artist, an Indian man rests his chin on his fist while looking at a dying general.

A Benjamin West painting depicts his son Benjamin Jr. and his other son, who had this first name. This is the first name of one of Charles Willson Peale’s sons, who shares this first name with the artist of The School of Athens.
answers: Benjamin West (The other painting is “The Death of General Wolfe.”)
Raphael [or Raphael West; or Raphaelle Peale; or Raphael Sanzio da Urbino; prompt on Sanzio]

bonuses.leadin: al-Rashid declared himself sultan after his 1666 entry into this city, where he established the Kasbah Cherarda. For 10 points each:
parts: Moroccan rulers have historically worn red tasselled hats named in English for what Moroccan city?
al-Rashid’s takeover of Fez marked the beginning of the dominance of this current ruling dynasty of Morocco. Under this dynasty, Fez intermittently served as Morocco’s capital until 1912.

In Fez, al-Rashid established the “Cherratine” example of an institution of this name. Fez’s “Bou Inania,” which was founded under the Marinids, is one of these religious or secular schools in the Arab world.
answers: ’Alawi dynasty [or Alawite dynasty or Alaouite dynasty or ’Alawid dynasty or Filali dynasty]
madrasas [or medersas or madrasahs or madrassas or madrasats or madaris; accept Cherratine Madrasa or Bou Inania Madrasa]

bonuses.leadin: An author who took her name from these plants described a girl becoming a chef for her friend and his trans mother in the novel Kitchen. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these plants. A poet abandoned his pen name of “unripe peach” after caring for one of these plants once made “disgusting” by “silvergrass.”
Matsuo Bashō praised his banana tree and other plants in these short Japanese poems with a pattern of five, seven, then five syllables per line.

This reclusive 8th century poet claimed his “thatched hut lacks all color” after a storm destroyed his prized conifer Nánmù. The speaker describes the “horses neighing and snorting” in this author’s poem “Ballad of the Army Carts.”
answers: bananas [accept banana trees; accept Banana Yoshimoto; accept bashō or Matsuo Bashō; prompt on trees]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~23524~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: In 2017, this archipelago was added to Google Street View after cameras were attached to wandering sheep. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this archipelago whose parliament, the Løgting, has a turf-covered roof. This archipelago’s native language is the closest relative of Icelandic.
Sheep confined to North Ronaldsay in the Orkneys developed an unusual diet of this food. Until the 1800s, Europeans harvested sodium carbonate from this food, which is used to make kombu in Japan.
According to legend, the Jacob sheep washed up in Britain during a failed military campaign launched by this country. The Manchega breed is native to this country’s La Mancha region.
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Geography - Europe> ~22987~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: A 2023 study found that several individuals vaccinated against COVID-19 developed antibodies against this molecule instead of the SARS spike protein. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this hydrophilic polymer which has been used for decades to shield drugs from the immune system, but was first put into vaccines in 2020.
PEG is required because the mRNA vaccines are formulated inside nanoparticles made from this class of hydrophobic macromolecules. These molecules include fats and oils.
The anti-PEG antibodies can be distracted by free PEG with a high value for this quantity. Polymer length is usually reported in units for this quantity like kilodaltons.
answers: molecular weight [or MW; or molar mass; or molecular mass; or MM; prompt on weight or mass or size]
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~19274~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: This woman ran for Congress on the slogan, “A woman’s role is in the House!” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this conservative who wrote the book A Choice Not an Echo, in which she criticized Rockefeller Republicans.
Phyllis Schlafly was a prominent opponent of this proposed amendment, originally drafted by Alice Paul, which would have made discrimination on the basis of sex unconstitutional.

In the 2000s, Schlafly led an impeachment campaign against this Supreme Court justice for his majority opinion in Roper v. Simmons. This retired justice wrote the majority opinion in Lawrence v. Texas.

bonuses.leadin: Michel-Rolph Trouillot (“twoo-YOH”) criticized how anthropology treats non-Western cultures and relegates them to a “slot” named for this word. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this adjective that appears in the title of a book that contrasts engineers with bricoleurs, who exemplify a way of thinking named for this word.
“Primitive” scientific thought is argued to be complex and organized by myth in The Savage Mind by this French structuralist anthropologist, who had a hyphenated surname.
Trouillot critiqued anthropology in multiple books on culture and history in this home country of his. A revolt in this country is analyzed in C. L. R. James’s The Black Jacobins.
answers: savage [accept “Anthropology and the Savage Slot”; accept The Savage Mind or La Pensée Sauvage]
Haiti [or Republic of Haiti; or République d’Haïti; or Repiblik d Ayiti]
bonuses.metadata: Ethan Ashbrook, Social Science - Anthropology> ~23260~ <Editor: Vincent Du

bonuses.leadin: This man claimed that dialect did not possess enough emotional subtlety in his introduction to a poetry anthology. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this author of a novel in which the anonymous narrator is taken on a tour of Europe by a patron known as the Rich White Gentleman. This man also wrote the lyrics to “Lift Every Voice and Sing.”
The title character of Johnson’s novel The Autobiography of an Ex-Colored Man grows up and experiences racism in this southern state. Gone With the Wind is set in this state during the Civil War.
A key scene in The Autobiography of an Ex-Colored Man takes place when the narrator realizes that a woman he’s admiring at a performance of this opera is actually his half-sister.
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Literature - American - Long Fiction> ~22426~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: A corollary to the Schwarz lemma gives when functions are constrained to multiply inputs by values in this set. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this set that is the image of the function “f-of-x equals e to the i x,” for x in the real numbers.

This function of theta equals the length of the vertical side of a right triangle with angle theta and vertices on the origin, horizontal axis, and unit circle. This function equals “opposite over hypotenuse.”

The Schwarz lemma follows from a “principle” named for the modulus with this property. The function “sine-of-theta” has this property only when theta equals pi-over-two plus an integer multiple of two pi.
answers: maximum [accept local maximum; accept word forms in place of “maximum,” like “maxima,” “maximal,” or “maximized”; prompt on answers describing the function being equal to one]
bonuses.metadata: David Bass, Science - Math> ~22125~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: Anne Dufourmantelle’s book “In Praise of [this concept]” became popular after she died while saving two drowning children in 2017. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this uncertainty that a negative outcome may occur, to which cautious people may be “averse.”
This thinker imagined a threshold at which imposing risk on someone is itself a violation of their rights. This thinker described a “night-watchman state” in the book Anarchy, State, and Utopia.

Hans Jonas’s “Ethics of the Future” formulated this risk-management approach that encourages preventative action when harm is possible. The UN’s Rio Declaration adopted this approach in its sustainability work.
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, RMP - Philosophy> ~22939~ <Editor: Vincent Du

bonuses.leadin: In 2019, the FDA warned Kimera Therapeutics that it did, in fact, require approval to use this process to harvest drugs from cell cultures. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process by which cells secrete cargo using vesicles.
Exosomes harvested from exocytosis could be good for drug delivery because they’re small enough to bypass the barrier that separates this organ in the CNS from central blood circulation.

Exosomes loaded with this enzyme have been sent across the blood-brain barrier as a preclinical treatment for Parkinson’s disease. This heme-containing enzyme is downstream of superoxide dismutase in cellular ROS detoxification pathways.
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Biology> ~23381~ <Editor: Adam Silverman
